answer: The Let's Play series for Baldur's Gate 3 consists of longer episodes with sub-episodes within, featuring chapter markers for easy breaks. Episodes are released every other day. The series is played on the balanced difficulty level to provide a challenge for viewers and to align with the difficulty level most people will be playing on. The player's morality for the run is undecided at the beginning. The series is kept in its own separate playlist. The player also plans to release a separate video for character
ground_truth: Longer episodes with sub episodes within and chapter markers. The episodes will be released every other day or so.

And I'll probably release an episode every other day or so.  This series will, of course, be kept in its own separate playlist.

answer: As stated in Document[1], choosing the Elf race grants advantages such as advantage on saving throws against being charmed and immunity to magic sleep effects. Additionally, Wood Elves, a subrace of Elves, receive a 5 feet increase to movement speed.
ground_truth: Elfs receive a movement speed increase, have proficiency with longswords, shortswords, shortbows or longbows and have the Fey ancestry.

answer: The Githyanki race has a special ability called "Astral Knowledge," which grants them proficiency in all skills of a chosen ability. [Document[1]]
ground_truth: Astral knowledge that allows the race to gain proficiency in all skills of a chosen ability.

meta.source_context: The Githyanki race does come with astral knowledge, which was not in Early Access. Gain proficiency in all skills of a chosen ability.

ground_truth: A non-lethal attack against an enemy that possibly dazes them.

answer: Hunter's Mark is a spell that can be cast by rangers in the game. It allows the ranger to mark a creature as their quarry, dealing additional damage whenever they hit it with a weapon attack. If the target dies, the ranger can mark a new creature without expending a spell slot. [1][2][4][8]
ground_truth: Has 1-6 damage and you can mark a creature as your quarry to deal an additional 1-6 damage whenever you hit it with a weapon attack. If the target dies before the spell ends, you can mark a new creature without expending a spell slot.

answer: The character's armor preference is heavy armor. This is because they mention wanting to be a strength-based, heavy armor-wearing ranger and express a desire to find better heavy armor. They also mention wanting to increase their constitution for tankiness and have a helmet that provides a bonus to dexterity saving throws. (Document[2], Document[5], Document[9])
ground_truth: The characters armor preference is heavy armor.

answer: The main quest of the game is to find the Night Song, a storied artifact, and bring it to the Arcanist of Atkatla in Baldur's Gate for a large sum of money. The Night Song is supposedly hidden in a temple, possibly in the goblin camp, and a map leading to it was held by the dwarf Brian, who was killed by goblins. Retrieving the Night Song is the focus of the game's main storyline. (Document[1])

answer: Looting in the game is important for several reasons. It allows players to obtain valuable items, such as weapons, armor, and magical artifacts, which can improve their characters' abilities and make them more powerful in combat [2]. Additionally, looting can provide players with resources, such as food and camp supplies, which are necessary for survival and resting [4]. Looting also allows players to collect gold and other currencies, which can be used to purchase items and services from traders [8]. Overall
ground_truth: Gather valuable items, stock up on camp supplies, lore as well as gold

answer: The potion of speed in the game provides several benefits, including boosting armor class and movement speed, as well as granting additional actions. It is similar to the haste spell and can be used strategically during combat encounters. [Document[1], Document[2]]
ground_truth: Boosts the characters armor class, movement speed and grants them more actions.

answer: The potion of mind reading allows the drinker to probe into the minds of those around them and read their thoughts. It also enables them to read the thoughts of certain creatures while speaking to them. [Document[5]]

answer: As stated in Document[1], the Harpers are a secretive faction in the Forgotten Realms who fight for good and try to ensure that no one faction or individual has too much power. They work to reduce power imbalances and maintain balance in the realms.
ground_truth: The Harpers are a secretive faction in the Forgotten Realms. They are a good faction and try to ensure that not one faction or city or individual has too much power in the realm

answer: Ceremorphosis is a process where a parasite turns its host into a mind flayer. It is a deadly condition that the speaker and others are trying to avoid. The speaker's condition is related to the parasite, but it gives them powers and telepathic connections without turning them into a mind flayer, at least not yet (Document[2], Document[3], Document[4]).
ground_truth: It is the process in which a parasite turns its host, after a period of excrucitating gestation, into a mind flayer.

meta.source_context: The uncertainty we speak of, this parasite. Are you aware that after a period of excruciating gestation, it will turn us into mind flayers? It's a process known as ceremorphosis, and let me assure you, it is to be avoided.

answer: As stated in Document[2], choosing the necromancy subclass for a wizard allows them to gain the ability called Grim Harvest. This ability allows the wizard to regain hit points equal to twice the spell slot level used when they kill a creature with a spell, or thrice the spell slot level if it's a necromancy spell. Additionally, as mentioned in Document[4], choosing the necromancy subclass makes necromancy spells cheaper for the wizard to learn.
ground_truth: Learning necromancy spells from scrolls only cost you 25 gold per spell level, not 50. Additionally, it gives you the Grim Harvest feature.

meta.source_context: You walk through the valley of the shadow of death and make lots of friends there, learning necromancy spells from Scrolls only costs you 25 gold or spell level at 50. Then we gain two spell slots. Our necromancy features Grim Harvest. Once per turn, if you kill a creature with a spell, you regain hit points equal to twice the spell slot level used. Thrice if it's a necromancy spell. Undead and constructs are unaffected.

answer: The concept of multi-classing in the game allows players to combine different classes to create powerful combinations. However, it comes at the expense of higher level class features, and players can only level up one class at a time. (as stated in Document[1])
ground_truth: It allows you to build powerful combinations of classes at the expense of higher level class features. You can only level up one class at a time.

answer: The cantrip 'Guidance' is described as one of the most useful cantrips in the game, and it is recommended to be used on pretty much every dialogue roll. It provides a bonus to skill checks and can help with persuasion, deception, and other dialogue-related actions. It is particularly useful in ensuring the success of dialogue options and can have an impact on the game's outcomes. (Document[1], Document[2])
ground_truth: When used it provides an additional bonus of 1-4 points to a dice roll.

meta.source_context: Guidance is one of the most useful cantrips in the game. Use it on pretty much every dialogue roll. And without it, I would have failed right there.

answer: As stated in Document[1], scrolls can be used by wizards to learn new spells. Instead of using the scroll itself, wizards study the scroll to gain knowledge of the spell. In the game, the protagonist learns new spells by right-clicking on the scroll and selecting "learn spell" (Document[1]). However, the protagonist's level may limit their ability to learn certain spells (Document[1]).
ground_truth: They can used to learn spells, provide information or lore about the the game and can be sold for gold.

meta.source_context: Scroll of Firebolt and Scroll of Ice Knife. Nice. So let's go ahead and learn these spells. As students of the Arcane Arts, wizards can learn new spells by studying certain spell scrolls instead of using them.

answer: At the Camp, you can take a long rest to fully heal your party, manage party members' relationships, store items, change your character, and recruit more followers. You can also use chests to store items and craft recipes. [1]
ground_truth: At the Camp, players can take a long rest to fully heal the party, manage relationships inside the group and change characters.

meta.source_context: At your Camp, you can take a long rest and fully heal your party. You can also manage party members' advanced relationships with your companions, store items, and eventually change your character and recruit more followers.

answer: As stated in Document[1], if the characters don't find a cure, they will experience symptoms such as fever, memory loss, hallucinations, hair loss, bleeding from every orifice, changes in bone structure, and transformation into a mind flayer. This ultimately results in the person ceasing to exist and a mind flayer being born.
ground_truth: It starts with a fever and memory loss. Then you start to hallucinate. Your hair falls out and you bleed from every orifice. Your bones will change form. Your jaw will split to allow room for four great tentacles. Your skin will turn to gore and be shed to reveal new flesh underneath. Then you have ceased to exist, and a mind flayer is born.

meta.source_context: Yes, great detail. Starts with a fever and memory loss. Then you start to hallucinate. Your hair falls out and you bleed from every orifice. Your bones will change form. Your jaw will split to allow room for four great tentacles. Your skin will turn to gore and be shed to reveal new flesh underneath. Then you have ceased to exist, and a mind flayer is born.

ground_truth: When equipped the helm provides the character with a level 1 illusion spell called shapeshift. It allows the player to shapeshift into one of the many different beings of the game such as a Dragonborn and Half-Orc.

answer: When the character takes a long rest, they recharge their spell slots and call their animal companion back. They also have the opportunity to talk to their companions and address any concerns or questions they may have. They can also use this time to prepare spells, organize their items, and store books. Additionally, during the long rest, the character may have encounters or conversations with other characters in the game.
ground_truth: Using the required amount of camp supplies fully rests the character, recovering all hitpoints, spell slots and short rests. Not using enough camp supplies only partially recovers the resources.

meta.source_context: Let's go ahead and take our long rest. Use the required amount of camp supplies to fully rest, recovering all your hit points, spell slots, and short rests.

answer: A soul coin is a precious item that contains souls and can be used to power infernal engines, which are massive war machines used in the Blood War between devils and demons. It is mentioned in Document[2] and Document[3].
ground_truth: These coins can power infernal engines, those engines are massive war machines that are used in the Blood War, the war between devils and demons.

answer: The purpose of the guidance cantrip in the game is to provide a useful tool for dialogue rolls, as stated in Document[1]. It is one of the most useful cantrips in the game and is used on pretty much every dialogue roll. It provides a bonus to the roll and can help the player succeed in conversations and interactions with NPCs.
ground_truth: It's a cantrip that clerics and druids have access to and provides a bonus to ability checks which lasts for 10 turns.

answer: When the speaker critically fails at a skill check, they will fail the check regardless of their ability modifier. The critical failure results in a negative outcome for the speaker. (Document[1])
ground_truth: Crtically failing at a skill check results in fail no matter what ability modifiers are active.

meta.source_context: Oh my gosh, critical failure. You've rolled a one on the skill check. Minus one. Critically failing at a skill check will mean you'll fail no matter what your ability modifier is.

answer: Answering is not possible given the available information.
ground_truth: Before taking a long rest it is advisable to check in with your companions as they oftentimes have new scenes or may want to discuss the events of the previous day with you, furthering your relationships with them in the process.

meta.source_context: And for those of you guys that might be new to this genre or this game in general, didn't play Early Access, every time you take a long rest, it's probably a good idea to check in with your companions because they oftentimes will have new scenes for you, they want to discuss the events of the previous day.

answer: As stated in Document[2], the Assassin subclass for the Rogue character provides several benefits. These include having advantage on attack rolls against creatures that haven't taken a turn yet, any successful attack role against a surprise creature being a critical hit, and restoring your action and bonus action at the start of combat. These features allow the Rogue to deal high damage and excel in surprise attacks.
ground_truth: In combat you have advantage on attack rolls against creatures that haven't taken a turn yet, guaranteed critical hits on successful attack roles against suprised creatures, and you immediately restore action and bonus actions at the of combat.

answer: The Druids are forcing people out of the Grove because they believe that outsiders are drawing in monsters and causing harm to the area. They have started a ritual to cut off the Grove from the outside world, and while some refugees are permitted to stay temporarily, the Druids are prioritizing the survival of the Grove. [Document[1]]
ground_truth: The Druids are forcing people out of the Grove because they believe that outsiders, like the refugees and the player character, are drawing monsters to the area.

answer: The Grove is being locked down because the Druids believe that it is necessary to protect themselves from the increasing number of monster attacks in the region. They blame outsiders for drawing the monsters to the Grove and have started a ritual to cut off the Grove from the outside world. They claim that there are not enough supplies to support everyone, so they are forcing people to leave. (Document[1], Document[2], Document[3])
ground_truth: The Druids have started a ritual to cut off the Grove from the outside world and are blaming the outsiders for the attacks.

meta.source_context: Are you really locking down the Grove? I know it's drastic, but more monsters seem to terrorize this region every day.

answer: The Blade of Frontiers, known as Wyll, is on a mission to kill Karlach, a powerful devil. Karlach is an archdevil soldier and a danger to the Sword Coast. However, it is later revealed that Karlach is not actually a devil, but a victim of the blood war who was forced to fight against her will. The two eventually form a truce and work together to fight against evil forces. (Document[1], Document[2], Document[5], Document
ground_truth: Wyll, the Blade of Frontiers, is on a mission to kill Karlach, a powerful devil. He has been tracking her through the hells to in order to prevent her from causing further harm.

meta.source_context: I've sworn my good eye to kill. I tracked her through the hells to the mind flayer ship, but the damned lithids infected me before I could end her.

answer: Arabella is being held by the druids in The Druids Grove. The druids are forcing everyone, including the Tieflings, out of the Grove and have started a ritual to cut off the Grove from the outside world. The Tieflings are refugees and the druids blame them for drawing monsters to the Grove. The protagonist wants to save Arabella and convince the druids to stop the ritual, but it seems that the druids are not willing to listen. (Document[2
ground_truth: Arabella is being judged by the leader of the druids, Kagha.

answer: The 'Drow poison' is a powerful poison that can be coated on a weapon. Targets must succeed a Constitution Saving Throw or become Poisoned and fall Asleep. It is mentioned in Document[1].

answer: The function of the Drow poison is to coat a weapon with poison, causing targets to make a Constitution Saving Throw or become Poisoned and fall Asleep [Document 1].
ground_truth: The function of the Drow poison is to coat your active weapon with poison, causing targets to become Poisoned and fall Asleep if they fail a Constitution Saving Throw.

answer: Ans: If targets fail the Constitution Saving Throw after being hit by a weapon coated with Drow poison, they become Poisoned and fall Asleep (as stated in Document[1]).
ground_truth: Targets who fail the Constitution Saving Throw after being hit by a weapon coated with Drow poison become Poisoned and fall Asleep.

answer: The idol of Silvanus is a holy artifact that holds significance to the druids in the Grove. It is sacred to Silvanus, the ancient god of nature, and its theft by a devil has caused unrest and disruption in the community. The idol's recovery is seen as crucial to maintaining balance and harmony in the Grove [9].
ground_truth: The idol of Silvanus is significant because it represents the god of nature and is associated with the druids in the Grove.

meta.source_context: I took back the idol of Silvanus and the righteous resumed. The mural shows druids claiming the Grove in the name of the old oak Silvanus, god of nature. Silvanus is the Oakfather, one of the ancient gods of nature in the forest. The idol of Silvanus is significant because it represents the god of nature and is associated with the druids in the Grove. The idol of Silvanus plays a role in sealing the Grove and keeping it free from harm and intruders.

answer: When an attack misses with the Watcher's Guide, Death's Promise, the wielder's next attack roll against that target gains True Strike, which gives advantage on the attack roll. (Document[1])
ground_truth: When an attack misses with the Watcher's Guide, Death's Promise, the wielder's next attack roll against that target gains True Strike, giving advantage on the attack roll.

meta.source_context: When you miss an attack, you deal three bludgeoning damage. Plus one to saving throws is actually pretty significant for just a simple weapon upgrade. When the spear misses its target, the wielder's next attack roll against that target gains True Strike. True Strike gives advantage on the attack roll and the cantrip on its own isn't the greatest, but if you're getting it from a weapon, you don't really have to do anything. We completed the first part of the Druid's Grove and we're gonna have to head out to investigate the swamp.

answer: The character's intention towards Kagha is to confront her and stop her from taking control of the Grove. They view her as a threat and believe that imprisoning her is necessary to protect the balance of nature and prevent further chaos. (Document[6], Document[8], Document[9], Document[10])
ground_truth: The character has considered getting rid of Kagha, but is hesitant because they fear the retaliation of the Druids.

answer: As stated in Document[1], a wizard in Baldur's Gate is offering a huge sum of money to anyone who brings him the Night song.
ground_truth: The wizard in Baldur's Gate is offering a huge sum of money for the Night song.

meta.source_context: A wizard in Baldur's Gate is offering a huge sum of money to anyone who brings him the Night song. Night song is in some kind of Temple, it must be in the goblin camp. One of the adventurers, the dwarf Brian, has a map leading to the Night song. However, he was killed by goblins at the temple. We now have a new Quest called find the Night song.

answer: The speaker has a positive opinion about having an animal companion. They mention that having an animal companion is more fun and that it allows them to deal more damage in their attacks. They also express a preference for having an animal companion in their party and mention that as long as companions like them, they will hang out with them for the majority of the game. (Document[4])
ground_truth: The speaker believes that having an animal companion is more fun and can help deal more damage in the game.

meta.source_context: My animal companion is currently gone. I gotta start making better use out of my animal companion because if I don't, you might as well just play Hunter Ranger. But the animal companion, a lot of the Hunter Rangers subclass features will let you deal more damage on your attacks but if you have your animal companion, you're actually using your animal companion well. answer: The story of the Devil with the silver tongue is a fairy tale about a farmer who made a deal with the Devil. In exchange for the farmer's dearest fruit, the Devil granted him a bottomless coin purse. However, the farmer's dearest fruit turned out to be his beloved daughter. The story serves as a moral lesson about the dangers of making deals with the Devil, as the cost is always too great. [Document 1]

answer: The speaker believes that making a deal with a devil is not advisable and should be avoided. They view devils as untrustworthy and manipulative, stating that the cost of making a deal is always too great and that devils will require more from you than you are willing to give [Document[4]].
ground_truth: The speaker believes that making a deal with the devil is not worth it, as the cost is always too great and the devil will take everything from you.

meta.source_context: What are your thoughts on the devil? Will refuse him no matter how tempting the offer, no matter how delicious the feast he lays out for you. The cost is always too great. Don't worry, I have no interest in a devil's deal. But when he becomes your last hope, remember this, he'll require of you only what you're least ready to part with and then require more still. You might think you'd give up anything for a cure, but the devil won't take just anything, he'll take everything.

answer: As stated in Document[1], the speaker finds playing a front line ranger to be cool and interesting, as it adds variety to the usual gameplay of a ranger and makes the position more engaging. They appreciate the companions and spells that rangers have, which enhances their experience as a front line ranger.
ground_truth: The speaker finds playing a front line ranger to be cool and interesting because of the companions and spells that they have.

My father ran into some tough times when I was just a young lad, and to support my mother and I, he made a trade deal with a human farmer by the name of Brem from the nearby town of Daggerford.  Brem was a good man, and my father, mother, and I would often join him and his family for dinner on his beautiful homestead.  The bad times have become good times, but all good things, of course, come to an end.  A sect of Shadow Druids would find out about this trade deal.  In one night while we were visiting Bram and his family, they came.  They did not approve of elves of the forest working in any way, shape, or form with farmers.  When their eyes are a curse on the land, they kill everyone except my mother and I, who were left trapped in the burning home.  A heavy wooden pillar came crashing down on my mother's head, knocking her unconscious and trapping her body underneath.  But I was weak and I could not move it.  I ran and screamed for help and screamed at the forest in hopes that a shadow Druid might show the slightest sign of sympathy and come back and help my mother out.  But no one came, and the house turned to ash.  I spent the next 15 years of my life as an Outlander, living in isolation but ever on the lookout for shadow Druids.  My only friends were that of the creatures of the forest, and one day I stumbled across a lone baby wolf in a fern patch.  I named her Fern.  She would join me on my quest.  I continued to train to ensure that I would never ever be weak again.  The first day that I met another Shadow Druid would be their last day on Faerun.  On my way to investigate the Cloakwood Forest to the South, a large shadow spread across the ground, and the last thing I remember is looking up to see a gigantic tentacle swooping down.  So that's the story of my strength-based Ranger.  The backstory doesn't like Shadow Druids too much.  Let's go ahead and choose Elf.  And look at all the races in this game. answer: The speaker finds Fighters to be bland compared to Rangers, as they believe that Rangers have more interesting abilities, such as companions and unique spells, that make the front line position more engaging. They appreciate the versatility and distinctiveness that Rangers offer. (Document[2])
ground_truth: The speaker finds front line Rangers more interesting than Fighters because of their Companions and spells.

ground_truth: The Tieflings were asked to make a trip to Baldur's Gate to escape being trapped by the goblins who still infest the roads.

meta.source_context: The Tiefling are not being kicked out anymore, but they do have to make the trip to Baldur's Gate at some point. Zevolor asked us to take out the goblin leaders in the area if we could, to make their journey a little bit easier. I should probably offload a few of my items that I'm not currently using. The goblins still infest the roads. As long as their leaders live, Zevlor's people are trapped. I'm going to dismiss Lae'zel, but only a Githyanki's safest can cleanse an embedded tadpole.

answer: Karlach is a Tiefling and an archdevil soldier who is being hunted by the blade of Frontiers, a monster hunter named Wyll. She has an infernal engine as her heart and is in need of an infernal mechanic to stabilize it. She was part of the blood war and fought in Zariel's army against her will. She is currently with the group and looking for someone to tune up her engines. (Document 1, 4, 8)

answer: Karlach is a Tiefling character who has an infernal engine as her heart. She is a level 3 Barbarian and was previously a soldier in the archdevil Zariel's army, fighting in the blood war. Karlach is being hunted by the blade of Frontiers, Wyll, who wants to kill her because she is a danger to the Sword Coast. Karlach is searching for an infernal mechanic to tune up her engine and stabilize it [1][4][

answer: As stated in Document[2], Wyll made a pact with Mizora, who grants him the power to conjure armor and cast Eldritch blasts. The exact terms and circumstances of the pact are forbidden to be uttered, but Wyll claims that he has no regrets and considers it his proudest deed.
ground_truth: Wyll and Mizora made a deal, with Wyll being Mizora's patron and the source of his power.

answer: Wyll is a character who joins the player's group in the game. He is known as the "blade of Frontiers" and has a backstory involving saving a child from goblins. His appearance includes a stone eye, which is made from pure bloodstone and serves as a reminder of the sacrifices that must be made. (Document[2])

ground_truth: The cause of the speaker's unhealing wound is Lady Shar's influence, which is also the reason for the terrible pain they experience.

ground_truth: Lady Shar is a revered figure among her followers, who believe that pain is sacred and leads to the peace of her eternal darkness.

answer: Cazador is a vampire lord in Baldur's Gate who turned the speaker into a vampire spawn nearly 200 years ago. The speaker was attacked by a gang of thugs and Cazador saved them by offering eternal life. The speaker became Cazador's spawn and has been under his control ever since (Document[2]).
ground_truth: Cazador is a vampire lord who turned the speaker into a vampire nearly 200 years ago after the speaker was attacked by a gang of thugs.

meta.source_context: Cazador is a vampire lord in Boulder's Gate, head of his coven and a monster obsessed with power. He turned me nearly 200 years ago. I became his spawn and he became my tormentor. A gang of thugs attacked me, angry about a ruling that I'd handed down as Magistrate. They beat me to death's door when Cazador appeared.

answer: As stated in Document[1], the Let's Play series features the narrator as the player character, a Wood Elf from the Misty Forest. In Document[2], the narrator meets a character named Scratch who is looking after his injured friend. In Document[3], the narrator encounters a character named Nine-Fingers Keene, the leader of a criminal organization in Baldur's Gate. In Document[4], the narrator interacts with various characters named Minster, David, and Kerwin. In
ground_truth: The characters we met in Episode 1 of Baldur's Gate 3 Let's Play Series are Asterion, Shadowheart, and Gale.

meta.source_context: In Episode 1, we were captured by a nautiloid ship and infected with a parasite in our brain, which we learned will ultimately turn us into a mind flayer if we don't do anything about it. We also met several characters as we wandered the material plane after that nautiloid ship crashed, which includes Asterion, Shadowheart, and Gale. Lae'zel is currently back at our camp. We are currently searching for a way to be cured of this parasite. We did hear that there's a Healer named Nettie in a camp nearby, so I think we're going to pursue that. But Lae'zel has also said that she could bring us to a Gethianki crash where her people would purify us, whatever that means. We did discover some ruins in Episode 1, but didn't fully explore them. So let's go ahead and head back to the ruins right here and actually go inside this time and see what's going on.

answer: As stated in Document[10], the wearer's weapon deals additional damage when they are healed.
ground_truth: The additional effect that the wearer's weapon has when they are healed is that it becomes coded in Magic and deals an additional 1d6 poison damage.

answer: Assisting Gale in locating magic items is important because it helps him manage a chronic condition that requires him to absorb the weave inside powerful magical artifacts. Without these items, Gale's condition deteriorates, leading to muscle spasms, disorientation, and potentially death [Document2].
ground_truth: The significance of the reader's assistance in locating magic items for the narrator is that the narrator, who is a wizard with a chronic impairment, needs these items for self-defense. The narrator used to have a supply of artifacts in their tower, but it has run dry. The items they need are not easily found in shops and usually require dangerous or costly efforts to obtain. The narrator believes that having these items is crucial for their survival, and the reader's help could be the difference between life and death for them.

answer: If Gale doesn't consume the artifacts, he will experience biological deterioration, including muscle spasms, disorientation, and a slight ringing in the ears. If left untreated, his condition can be deadly (Document[1]).
ground_truth: If the speaker doesn't consume the artifacts for their condition, they will experience biological deterioration, muscle spasms, disorientation, and a slight ringing in the ears. If this condition persists for too long, it can become deadly. The speaker mentions that it has been days since they last consumed an artifact, indicating that their craving for it will eventually return.

meta.source_context: What it comes down to is this: every so often, I need to get my hands on a powerful magical item and absorb the weave inside. And what happens if you don't consume these artifacts? I'll spare you the finer details, but it begins with a simple biological deterioration, muscle spasms, disorientation, a slight ringing in the ears. And if it's there for too long, it's deadly. It's been days since I last consumed an artifact before we were abducted. It's only a matter of time before my craving returns.

answer: The spell Warding Bond grants resistance to all damage and a boost to armor class and saving throws to both the caster and their ally. However, each time the ally takes damage, the caster also takes the same amount of damage. The spell lasts until a long rest. (Document[1])
ground_truth: The spell Warding Bond offers pain resistance to damage, a plus one to Armor class and saving throws. It lasts until a long rest and does not require concentration.

meta.source_context: It gives pain resistance to damage and a plus one to their Armor class and saving throws.   And it lasts until a long rest, and it doesn't require concentration.

answer: The characters in Episode 1 of the Baldur's Gate 3 Let's Play Series are the narrator/host, who is playing as a Wood Elf, and various companions including Wyll, Asterion, Shadowheart, and Gale. The brain parasite can be cured by finding a healer named Nettie or by going to a Githyanki crash with Lae'zel.
ground_truth: The characters in Episode 1 of the Baldur's Gate 3 Let's Play Series are Asterion, Shadowheart, Gale, and Lae'zel. To cure the brain parasite, the options mentioned are seeking help from a healer named Nettie in a nearby camp or going with Lae'zel to a Gethianki crash where her people can purify them.

meta.source_context: In Episode 1, we were captured by a nautiloid ship and infected with a parasite in our brain, which we learned will ultimately turn us into a mind flayer if we don't do anything about it. We also met several characters as we wandered the material plane after that nautiloid ship crashed, which includes Asterion, Shadowheart, Gale, and Lae'zel. Lae'zel is currently back at our camp. We are currently searching for a way to be cured of this parasite. We did hear that there's a Healer named Nettie in a camp nearby, so I think we're going to pursue that. But Lae'zel has also said that she could bring us to a Gethianki crash where her people would purify us, whatever that means. So we have a couple of different options here. But we did discover some ruins in Episode 1, but didn't fully explore them.

answer: As stated in Document[1], Wood Elves in Faerun's forests have a deep connection with nature and honed skills in archery and camouflage. The Wood Elf subrace's racial traits, such as darkvision and Fey ancestry (advantage on saving throws against being charmed and magic can't put them to sleep), enhance their abilities in these areas. Darkvision allows them to see in darkness, aiding in their stealth and archery skills, while Fey ancestry protects them against magical influences that
ground_truth: The Wood Elf subrace's racial traits, such as darkvision and Fey ancestry, contribute to their archery and camouflage skills in Faerun's forests in several ways.  Firstly, darkvision allows Wood Elves to see in darkness as if it were dim light, giving them an advantage when navigating through the forest at night or in areas with low light. This ability helps them to spot potential targets or threats more easily, enhancing their archery skills. Secondly, Fey ancestry provides Wood Elves with advantage on saving throws against being charmed and immunity to being put to sleep by magic. This resistance to magical effects helps them to remain focused and alert while hunting or hiding, making them less susceptible to distractions or enchantments that could hinder their archery or camouflage abilities. Additionally, the Wood Elf subrace's reclusive lives in Faerun's forests and their decades of training in archery and camouflage are further enhanced by an otherworldly swiftness. This swiftness, which is likely a result of their Fey ancestry, allows them to move quickly and silently through the forest, making it easier for them to find advantageous positions for archery or to blend seamlessly into their surroundings for camouflage. Overall, the combination of darkvision, Fey ancestry, and their otherworldly swiftness greatly contributes to the Wood Elf subrace's archery and camouflage skills in Faerun's forests, giving them a significant advantage in their reclusive lives and making them formidable hunters and scouts.

meta.source_context: We get darkvision, which is a really good racial feature in this game. And also Fey ancestry, you have advantage on saving throws against being charmed and magic can't put you to sleep, which is also nice. And for our subrace, we're gonna go the Wood Elf. These elves spend their reclusive lives in Faerun's forests. Decades of training in archery and camouflage are enhanced by an otherworldly swiftness.

And how were you turned? Did he attack you? Not him, no.  A gang of thugs attacked me, angry about a ruling that I'd handed down as Magistrate.  They beat me to death's door when Cazador appeared.  He chased them off and offered to save me, to give me eternal life.  Given that my choices were eternal life or bleed to death on the street, I took him up on the offer.  It was only afterward I realized just how long eternity could be.   You've been a slave ever since? A spawn is less than a slave.  We have no choice but to obey our master's commands.  They speak and our bodies react.  It's all part of the deal.  Sometimes he'd order us to submit to torture, sometimes he'd have us torture ourselves, whatever his weather vane mood settled on.   I love the difference in responses here.  You're free now, enjoy that freedom.  I will, but I won't take it for granted.  The Mind Flayers aren't the only monsters out there, and they might not be the only ones hunting us.  All I'm asking is that you keep your eyes open and watch out for anything lurking in the shadows.

answer: Accepting the offer of eternal life results in becoming a vampire spawn, which means being bound to obey the commands of the vampire lord who turned them. The vampire lord can order the spawn to submit to torture or inflict self-harm, and the spawn has no choice but to comply. It is a life of servitude and torment. (Document[10])
ground_truth: The consequence of accepting the offer of eternal life is that the person becomes a slave and must obey their master's commands.

answer: Casting Hunter's Mark as a hunter spell on the ranger's combat abilities grants an additional 1d6 damage to attacks against the targeted enemy [3]. It also allows the ranger to move through difficult terrain at normal speed, which is beneficial for maneuvering in battle [2].
ground_truth:
Casting Hunter's Mark as a hunter spell has the following effects on the ranger's combat abilities and movement speed:
- It allows the ranger to cast Hunter's Mark on an enemy and attack that enemy in the same turn, as it only costs a bonus action. - It requires concentration. - It does not rely on the ranger's wisdom modifier, making it a good choice for rangers with low wisdom. - It may limit the ranger's ability to pass Hunter's Mark around, as both casting the spell and using Longstrider require a bonus action. - Longstrider, when combined with the ranger's Wood Elf racial bonus, increases the creature's movement speed by 10 feet until a long rest. - The ranger's character will be highly mobile, moving all over the battlefield and getting close to the enemy. - The ranger has the option to choose from different fighting styles, such as archery, defense, dueling, and two weapon fighting. In this case, the ranger chooses defense, which provides a +1 bonus to their Armor class.

meta.source_context: This is a really, really good hunter spell, especially earlier on in the game, and it does require concentration, but it only costs a bonus action and a spell slot.   It's not an action, so I can cast Hunter's Mark on an enemy and then also attack that enemy in the same turn.   And since I have low wisdom as a ranger, I don't really have good wisdom, I want to stick to spells that don't work off of my wisdom modifier.   What I'm going to take here is Longstrider, increase the creature's movement speed by 10 feet, which lasts until a long rest.   And that kind of, you know it kind of messes with your ability to pass Hunter's Mark around as both require a bonus action, so I'm going to take longstrider, accompany longstrider with my what elf plus five movement speed.   My character is going to be going all over the battlefield and getting right into the enemy's faces.   And then for fighting style, we have archery, defense, dueling, and two weapon fighting.   And I'm gonna go ahead and take defense, which gives us a plus one to our Armor class.

ground_truth: The Grim Harvest feature offers the advantage of regaining hit points when a creature is killed with a spell. The amount of hit points regained is equal to twice the spell slot level used, or thrice if it's a necromancy spell. However, undead and constructs are unaffected by this feature. This feature encourages the use of spells from the necromancy School of magic. As for the paladin-rogue multiclass character, it is not mentioned how the Grim Harvest feature specifically benefits this combination.

answer: The Eldritch invocation 'agonizing blast' increases the damage of Eldritch blast by adding the character's charisma modifier to the damage. It does not directly interact with invocations like repelling blast or Devil's sight.
ground_truth: The impact of the Eldritch invocation 'agonizing blast' on the damage of Eldritch blast is that it adds the caster's charisma modifier to the damage dealt by Eldritch blast. This means that the damage of Eldritch blast is increased by the caster's charisma modifier. As for its interaction with invocations like repelling blast and Devil's sight, the information provided in the context does not directly address this. However, it is worth noting that repelling blast allows the caster to push a creature up to 15 feet away when they hit it with Eldritch blast. Devil's sight, on the other hand, enhances the caster's ability to see in darkness. Therefore, the impact of agonizing blast on the damage of Eldritch blast is clear, but further information is needed to determine its specific interaction with invocations like repelling blast and Devil's sight.

meta.source_context: When you cast Eldritch blast, add your charisma modifier to the damage that it deals. When you hit a creature with Eldritch blast, you can push the creature up to 15 feet away from you. I do want to try Devil's sight at some point and do like a melee build that lives in the darkness.

answer: The downside of using the warding bond spell is that each time the ally takes damage, the creature takes the same amount of damage. As stated in Document[1], "The downside to warding bond is, each time the ally takes damage, the creature takes the same amount of damage."
ground_truth: The downside of using the warding bond spell in terms of damage distribution between the ally and the creature is that each time the ally takes damage, the creature also takes the same amount of damage.

meta.source_context: The downside to warding bond is, each time the ally takes damage, the creature takes the same amount of damage.

answer: Answering is not possible given the available information.
ground_truth: The person became a vampire when Cazador offered to save them after they were beaten by a gang of thugs.

meta.source_context: He turned me nearly 200 years ago. A gang of thugs attacked me, angry about a ruling that I'd handed down as Magistrate. They beat me to death's door when Cazador appeared. He chased them off and offered to save me, to give me eternal life. Given that my choices were eternal life or bleed to death on the street, I took him up on the offer. It was only afterward I realized just how long eternity could be.

answer: As stated in Document[2], if a person transforms into a mind flare, they no longer exist as themselves. The mind flare takes over their memories and soul. Document[3] also mentions that when someone transforms, they experience symptoms such as fever, memory loss, hallucinations, and physical changes like hair loss and bleeding from orifices. The transformation results in a mind flare being born.
ground_truth: When you transform into a mind flare in the game, you essentially cease to exist as the mind flare takes over your memories and soul.

meta.source_context: If this game actually lets you turn into a mind flare, the main problem with that is when somebody does turn into a mind flare, that person is basically gone. answer: The spell Warding Bond grants resistance to all damage and a boost to Armor Class to the caster and a chosen ally. However, each time the ally takes damage, the caster also takes the same amount of damage. The duration of the spell is not mentioned in the given documents.
ground_truth: The effects of the spell Warding Bond include pain resistance to damage, a plus one bonus to Armor class and saving throws. The duration of the spell lasts until a long rest, and it does not require concentration.

meta.source_context: It gives pain resistance to damage and a plus one to their Armor class and saving throws. And it lasts until a long rest, and it doesn't require concentration.
